habitat: Grasslands of North America and Europe; grows in grassy fields, especially after rain, often in areas with manure. Cultivated worldwide in over 70 countries.
shortDescription: The most popular edible mushroom globally, consumed in its button, crimini, and portobello forms. White to brown caps, pink to brown gills, meaty texture, widely used in cooking.
edibility: Edible and widely cultivated; safe when cooked. Consumed in many forms such as button, crimini, and portobello mushrooms.
benefitsOrToxicity: Rich in vitamins (A, B, C, D) and minerals (phosphorus, potassium, calcium, iron). Contains antioxidants, supports immune system, digestive health, hormone regulation, and may have anti-inflammatory and anticancer properties. Raw mushrooms contain small amounts of agaritine and gyromitrin, reduced by cooking. Potential allergy risk. Excessive raw consumption may be harmful.

identification.cap: White or brown; 2.5–14 cm wide; convex to flat with growth; smooth or slightly scaly; bruises pinkish to reddish.
identification.gills: Free from stem; close together; pinkish when young, darkening to nearly black with age.
identification.stem: White, smooth or slightly scaly; 2–7 cm long, 1–2.5 cm thick; may bruise reddish-brown; thin ring often disappears with age.
identification.flesh: Firm and white; bruises pinkish-red, then brown.
identification.microscopicFeatures: Spores ellipsoid, 6–8 × 5–6 µm; smooth, thick-walled, brown in KOH. Cheilocystidia 20–30 µm long, clavate, thin-walled. No pleurocystidia.

medicinalProperties: Potential antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antibacterial, antifungal, anticancer, and genoprotective effects. May regulate hormones, support blood sugar control, promote digestive health, boost immunity, and aid skin regeneration.
note: Also known as crimini (brown variety) and portobello (mature form). Historically classified under Agaricus campestris and Psalliota species before being named Agaricus bisporus.
